H0.text: Chemical energy stored by the sandpaper is the result of thermal energy converted through friction when a carpenter rubs sandpaper on a wooden bench to make the bench smoother, causing the sandpaper to warm.

H1.text: Radiant energy that is transferred to the bench is the thermal energy converted by the friction between the sandpaper and the wooden bench when a carpenter rubs the sandpaper to smooth the bench.

H2.text: Potential energy that is stored by the wood is what the thermal energy is converted to when a carpenter rubs sandpaper on a wooden bench to make it smoother, generating friction and warming the sandpaper.

H3.text: Heat energy that is transferred to the air is produced as the carpenter rubs sandpaper on a wooden bench, converting thermal energy generated by friction between the sandpaper and the bench.

A4.text: In 1842, Julius Robert Mayer frictionally generated heat in paper pulp and measured the temperature rise.

A5.text: The careful experiments of Joule, who developed heat in various ways by the application of mechanical force, establish almost to a certainty, not only the possibility of increasing the quantity of heat, but also the fact that the newly-produced heat is proportional to the work expended in its production.
